title: RL33543
content: The report discusses the modernization of U.S. military tactical aircraft, including fighter aircraft, strike fighters, and attack planes. Tactical aircraft are crucial for U.S. military capability and defense spending. Efforts focus on three main aircraft acquisition programs: the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter program, the Air Force F-22 fighter program, and the Navy F/A-18E/F strike fighter program. Congress faces decisions in FY2010 regarding these programs, such as whether to terminate the alternate engine development for the F-35 and whether to end F-22 procurement at 187 aircraft. The report discusses the proposal to terminate the alternate engine program for the F-35, deciding on ending F-22 procurement at 187 aircraft, and funding requests for F/A-18E/Fs in FY2010. It also covers program-specific issues for the F-35, F-22, and F/A-18E/F programs in detail. The CRS reports RL30563, RL31673, and RL30624 discuss FY2010 legislative activity on U.S. tactical aircraft, focusing on affordability and the future of the U.S. industrial base. Tactical aircraft are combat planes that operate within a regional theater of operations without in-flight refueling. Aircraft are categorized as tactical or strategic based on their range and mission capabilities. Tactical aircraft, such as fighters and attack planes, operate within a single regional theater of operations. In contrast, strategic aircraft like B-52, B-1, and B-2 bombers are designed for longer-range missions, including intercontinental flights. Tactical aircraft are primarily used for air-to-air combat, with some air-to-ground capabilities. Fighters (e.g., F-22) are for air-to-air combat, while strike fighters (e.g., F-35) have dual roles in air-to-ground and air-to-air operations. Attack planes (e.g., A-10) focus on air-to-ground missions. Tactical aircraft, or tac air, operate from land bases for Air Force and carriers for Navy, with Marine Corps using both. Marine Corps tactical aircraft, including VSTOL and STOVL planes, operate from Navy ships, land bases, and expeditionary bases with short runways. They are used for air-to-air combat, air-to-ground missions like close air support and interdiction, and deep strike operations. Strike fighters can engage in both air-to-air and air-to-ground operations. The Air Force and Navy operate various tactical aircraft for air-to-air and air-to-ground operations. The Air Force has F-22, F-15, F-16, and A-10 aircraft, while the Navy has F/A-18A-D and F/A-18E/F fighters. The Marine Corps operates F/A-18 A-D and AV-8B VSTOL planes.
